body: @ncteisen Please don't review yet. I'm fixing some stuff in response to the failing tests.

___ *[src/core/lib/transport/metadata.h, line 352 at r3](https://reviewable.io/reviews/grpc/grpc/16488#-LM3FLn18H6mfPx6F8es:-LM3PgiM5v2G4HlQHZM2:b-l8ea3l) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/23f0ab38fb6f09dcbf9371e6d681515e36df85a1/src/core/lib/transport/metadata.h#L352)):*
Previously, markdroth (Mark D. Roth) wrote…
Why is this needed?
This typedef is the existing code.

___ *[src/core/lib/transport/metadata.h, line 352 at r3](https://reviewable.io/reviews/grpc/grpc/16488#-LM3FLn18H6mfPx6F8es:-LM3TGNB1YIjjJpFzdqJ:bndi72f) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/23f0ab38fb6f09dcbf9371e6d681515e36df85a1/src/core/lib/transport/metadata.h#L352)):*
Previously, markdroth (Mark D. Roth) wrote…
Sure. But why is the forward declaration needed here?
A quick code search shows that a lot of code refers to `grpc_mdelem` rather than `struct grpc_mdelem`. So I assume it's needed so that code that deals with metadata can avoid the `struct` keyword.

___ *[src/core/lib/transport/metadata.h, line 352 at r3](https://reviewable.io/reviews/grpc/grpc/16488#-LM3FLn18H6mfPx6F8es:-LM3ZnM6Eo07gf1pAlaX:b-4s2tkg) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/23f0ab38fb6f09dcbf9371e6d681515e36df85a1/src/core/lib/transport/metadata.h#L352)):*
Previously, markdroth (Mark D. Roth) wrote…
Sure, but why are you adding this in this PR? It looks like the same forward declaration already exists on line 63 above, so I don't think it needs to be duplicated here.
Oh I see. Didn't realize it got duplicated. Thanks for the catch!!

___ *[src/core/lib/transport/metadata.h, line 95 at r9](https://reviewable.io/reviews/grpc/grpc/16488#-LM8RhBEBNYlj-vYgsXo:-LM94ucw91ctT7hGFRdB:b81sw07) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/713f9bc93a94ee7859314725f6c6fd6836d2fce0/src/core/lib/transport/metadata.h#L95)):*
Previously, markdroth (Mark D. Roth) wrote…
Note that prior to this, `grpc_mdelem` contained only a pointer, so our code treats it as if it is one. For example, when having a function return a `grpc_mdelem`, we return it directly from the function rather than having the caller allocate it and pass in a pointer to be populated by the function. Similarly, when passing it into a function, we typically pass it by value instead of by reference. Adding another field here means that `grpc_mdelem` is no longer just the size of a pointer, which means that there will be more copying that happens when code passes a `grpc_mdelem` to a function or returns it from a function. This may add performance overhead. As an alternative, how about adding another bit to `grpc_mdelem_data_storage` that indicates that the value is an index instead of a pointer? In other words, if the `payload` field's 3rd bit is set, then the second byte can be used to indicate the index.
I don't think that will work because I need the pointer. Having access to the metadata data through the pointer is how I'm able to keep this change less invasive. I understand the performance overhead concern. How about this alternative: adding a one byte field to the grpc_mdelem_data struct that is the index? Then, grpc_mdelem will only contain a pointer as before and I can access the index through something like: #define GRPC_MDINDEX(md) (GRPC_MDELEM_DATA(md)->index) This should just increase the size of the table that holds the actual data for mdelems by one byte per mdelem, but not add the per-RPC copying overhead you were discussing. Please let me know what you think.

___ *[tools/codegen/core/gen_static_metadata.py, line 75 at r9](https://reviewable.io/reviews/grpc/grpc/16488#-LM8ewF51BEjb6L4WXi0:-LM96J8m2NmawBO3kLCh:b-jcvn90) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/713f9bc93a94ee7859314725f6c6fd6836d2fce0/tools/codegen/core/gen_static_metadata.py#L75)):*
Previously, markdroth (Mark D. Roth) wrote…
Are the specific indexes assigned to each element important, or is it just important that certain elements are in the static table and others are not? If the latter, then instead of putting the numbers here, I suggest just putting `True` and having the code below assign the numbers as it reads the elements of this list. That way, we won't have to maintain these manually (e.g., imagine needing to add a new element and trying to figure out what the last index already in use is).
Yes, the specific indices are important. They are equivalent to the hpack static table indices for those elements and enable the optimization of being able to directly encode the index in the hpack encoder. This means that if the hpack protocol changes, this file should also be changed.

___ *[tools/codegen/core/gen_static_metadata.py, line 75 at r9](https://reviewable.io/reviews/grpc/grpc/16488#-LM8ewF51BEjb6L4WXi0:-LM9M_lr-HDaWtfaO6wc:b-j4jkm9) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/713f9bc93a94ee7859314725f6c6fd6836d2fce0/tools/codegen/core/gen_static_metadata.py#L75)):*
Previously, markdroth (Mark D. Roth) wrote…
Hmm... Where do these numbers come from? Are they in the hpack RFC? If these numbers are really hpack-specific, then it seems like we're still breaking the abstraction here by encoding hpack-specific information in the transport-agnostic `grpc_mdelem` structure. What if there's some other transport in the future that has its own static table but uses different indices? I would prefer a solution where the data we encode in the `grpc_mdelem` struct is completely transport-agnostic. Is there any reasonable way to do that?
Yes, they are in Appendix A of the hpack RFC, which defines the static hpack table: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7541#appendix-A If there's some other transport in the future that wants to use this optimization but uses different indices, I suppose we could add a field for it in the grpc_mdelem_data struct, and then rename the fields so it's clear which transport they refer to. To be clear, encoding this information in the grpc_mdelem won't affect the functionality of using other transports. It seems like the concern here is about maintaining the abstraction. I currently can't think of a way to preserve this encoding optimization and keep the grpc_mdelem_data completely transport-agnostic, but I'd welcome any ideas on this.

___ *[tools/codegen/core/gen_static_metadata.py, line 75 at r9](https://reviewable.io/reviews/grpc/grpc/16488#-LM8ewF51BEjb6L4WXi0:-LMApYGY6C9AGDTniup3:b-o8n267) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/713f9bc93a94ee7859314725f6c6fd6836d2fce0/tools/codegen/core/gen_static_metadata.py#L75)):*
Previously, hcaseyal wrote…
Yes, they are in Appendix A of the hpack RFC, which defines the static hpack table: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7541#appendix-A If there's some other transport in the future that wants to use this optimization but uses different indices, I suppose we could add a field for it in the grpc_mdelem_data struct, and then rename the fields so it's clear which transport they refer to. To be clear, encoding this information in the grpc_mdelem won't affect the functionality of using other transports. It seems like the concern here is about maintaining the abstraction. I currently can't think of a way to preserve this encoding optimization and keep the grpc_mdelem_data completely transport-agnostic, but I'd welcome any ideas on this.
Ok so I can think of one idea, but it's slightly less performant than storing the hpack static index directly in the grpc_mdelem_data struct (aka, the solution we settled on in an above comment). We could store some grpc-defined index in the grpc_mdelem_data struct. A transport can have its own lookup array which essentially maps the grpc defined index to a transport defined index for that mdelem. This means that we have to index into this transport-defined array for each mdelem whereas with the other solution, we would already have the index. This solution breaks the dependency in one direction (grpc_mdelem_data would no longer depend on the transport).
